results.title: Pictorial sketching
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Engineering Drawing”.
Animated drawings and live photography are used in explaining the basic principles of pictorial sketching. Describes the three methods of pictorial sketching, and explains where and how to use each method. Demonstrates a step-by-step procedure for sketching, from the initial visualisation to the checking of the completed sketch.

results.title: Pictorial Parade No. 25. No random harvest
results.brief_description: New Zealand’s pine plantations, among the largest man-made forests in the world, are now producing the raw materials for timber and paper manufacture. New saw and paper mills have been built and existing plants enlarged. New railways and towns were also needed to service the industries created by this planned harvest of timber.

results.title: Picnic with Weismann = Picknick mit Weismann
results.creator_credit: A H Puluj, ACI Films and Jan Svankmajer
results.brief_description: An unusual, surrealistic recounting of a day’s outing. Inanimate objects (a man’s suit, a trowel, charis, an old gramophone) take on a life of their own. A wardrobe opens and a man, bound and gagged falls into a prepared grave.

results.title: Pickpocket [NTSC]
results.creator_credit: Agnes Delahaie, Agnes Delahaie Productions and Robert Bresson
results.brief_description: A film of dazzling originality, “Pickpocket” has exercised an enormous influence on directors as disparate as Fassbinder, Akerman, Scorsese, Aki Kaurismaki, Malle (who called it ‘one of four or five great dates in the history of cinema’), and Schrader (who pronounced it ‘an unmitigated masterpiece’ and lifted its ending for the denouement of his own “American Gigolo”). Loosely based on Dostoevsky’s “Crime and Punishment”, Bresson’s intense portrait of a compulsive pickpocket who believes himself above the moral constraints of common humanity, turns the mechanics of theft into a ritual both erotically and spiritually charged. The “ballets of thievery”, as Cocteau called them, are among the most beautifully choreographed and edited sequences in cinema. Cast: Martin Lasalle, Marika Green, Pierre Leymarie, Pierre Etaix. In French with English subtitles.

The “ballets of thievery”, as Cocteau called them, are among the most beautifully choreographed and edited sequences in cinema. Cast: Martin Lasalle, Marika Green, Pierre Leymarie, Pierre Etaix. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Pickpocket
results.creator_credit: Agnes Delahaie, Agnes Delahaie Productions and Robert Bresson
results.brief_description:
“Bresson’s masterpiece was voted the greatest postwar French film by ‘Cahiers du cinema’, which somehow doesn’t do it justice. As Rene Predal has argued, it is one of four films, along with Resnais’ ‘Hiroshima mon amour’, Antonioni’s ‘L’avventura’, and Godard’s ‘A Bout de Souffle’, that ‘constitute the quartet of germinal films of the modern cinema’. ‘Pickpocket’ has exercised an enormous influence on directors as disparate as Fassbinder, Akerman, Scorsese, Aki Kaurismaki, Malle (who called it ‘one of four or five great dates in the history of cinema’), and Schrader (who pronounced it ‘an unmitigated masterpiece’ and lifted its ending for the denouement of his own ‘American Gigolo’). Loosely based on Dostoevsky’s ‘Crime and Punishment’, Bresson’s intense portrait of a compulsive pickpocket who believes himself above the moral constraints of common humanity turns the mechanics of theft into a ritual both erotically and spiritually charged. The ‘ballets of thievery’, as Cocteau called them, are among the most beautifully choreographed and edited sequences in cinema. ‘A film of dazzling originality. On its first viewing, it risks burning your eyes. So, do like me: Go back to see it again every day … If you deny this film, it is cinema itself as an autonomous art that you call into question’ (Louis Malle).” Reference: James Quandt. The poetry of precision: the films of Robert Bresson. Cinematheque Ontario. Online. http://www.bell.ca/filmfest/cinematheque/bresson.htm. Further reading: Film Comment. ‘Special Bresson’. May/June and July 1999

Credits: Producer, Agnes Delahaie ; director, Robert Bresson ; writer, Robert Bresson ; photography, Leonce-Henri Burel ; music, Jean-Baptiste Lulli ; editing, Raymond Lamy.
Cast: Martin Lasalle, Marika Green, Pierre Leymarie, Pierre Etaix.

results.title: Pick up on South Street
results.creator_credit: Michael Capon, Post Office Telecommunications, Great Britain. Post Office. Telecommunications Safety Services Branch and Edward Hooker
results.brief_description: An instructional film about the correct way to handle heavy goods. “Its just like picking up a girl you have to have the know-how and the right equipment.”

results.title: Piccolo, saxo and company
results.creator_credit: Philips and Company, Joop Geesink's Dollywood Productions and Jan Coolen
results.brief_description: How the symphony orchestra was born. The string family of musical instruments met the brass family, and the woodwind family. They were joined by the family of drums and percussion, and eventually the Grand Piano completed the orchestra.

results.title: Picasso: war, peace & love
results.brief_description: From his epic “Guernica” to some of his last works. This film spans some thirty years of Picasso’s art. It includes many unfamiliar works as well as some unique live sequences of the artist in his studio near Cannes. NOTE: Film content is worthy of viewing but print condition is poor with excessive colour fade (pinkish-red tones).
